Award.AwardTitle: Travel Award for US-based Scientists to Attend Metabolic Pathway Analysis 2015 in Braga, Portugal

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1539847
Carlson, Ross P.

NSF support will help ensure the success of the meeting by partially defraying conference costs for select US academic scientists and engineers with an emphasis on underrepresented groups and graduate students. In the absence of NSF support, many US academic scientists and graduate students would not be able to attend and to benefit from interactions with the international community of metabolic analysis/engineering researchers.

This award supports the participation of US investigators and graduate students in the Metabolic Pathway Analysis meeting to be held in Braga, Portugal from June 8-12, 2015. The meeting has a primary focus on the structural (topological) analysis of metabolic networks, and in particular techniques allied to linear algebra, linear programming and computer modelling. This focus may be applied at many levels of abstraction, from individual reaction mechanisms, through pathways, organelles, whole organisms and, most recently, mixed populations. Covered topics will include Metabolic pathway analysis, Metabolic flux analysis, Elementary mode analysis, Metabolic modelling, Metabolic engineering, Genome scale modelling.

The award from the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-sponsored by the Synthetic and Systems Biology Program of the Molecular and Cell Biology Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific Merit: A major focus of modern biology is the study of complex systems comprised of components and interactions cataloged in rapidly growing databases. While the rate of data generation continues to accelerate, analysis of this data is often limited by computational tools and relevant theory. Metabolic structural modeling and analysis approaches are making advances in this field through quantification of phenotypes reflected by genomic, transcriptomic, metabolomic, proteomic, and fluxomic data. The Metabolic Pathway Analysis (MPA) 2015 conference held in Braga Portugal focused on topological analyses of metabolic networks and in particular techniques utilizing linear algebra, linear programming and computer modeling in conjunction with experimental data to decode biological principles. These analyses were applied at many levels of abstraction, from individual enzymes to biochemical pathways, organelles, whole organisms and mixed cellular populations. The conference research sessions spanned the gamut of fundamental and applied biology and include timely analysis of biofuels, photosynthesis, multicellular systems, environmental nutrient cycles, and human health. 

The broader impacts of the NSF award included 1) the education of 11 US-based scientists in the newest computational approaches for studying metabolic pathways, 2) the dissemination of US-based scientists’ approaches and data to an international audience, and 3) the opportunity for US-based scientists to establish new professional contacts and collaborations through face-to-face discussions. The NSF support enabled two graduate students, a post-doctoral scientist, a government scientist, four early stage professors and three established professors to attend the meeting. All supported scientists presented either an oral or a poster presentation and participated in the numerous lectures, breakout discussions and social events.  All supported travelers leveraged the NSF support to find additional funding sources, both public and private, to cover the costs associated with attending the conference including registration and food.
